titleproper.value:
Guide to the Papers of Robert Hunter
                    <lb/>
                    <date>1699-1744 </date>
                    <date>(Bulk 1710-1744)</date>
                    <lb/>
                    <num>MS 316</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Processed by Shannon Yule

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2011-10-25T16:05-0400</date>

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: Robert Hunter was a colonial governor of New York and New Jersey. His papers include correspondence, accounts, and legal documents.

p.value: Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to twenty exposures of stable, unbound material per day. (Researchers may not accrue unused copy amounts from previous days.)
This collection should be cited as Robert Hunter Papers, The New-York Historical Society.

Robert Hunter was born in Edinburgh, Scotland 1666. He was appointed governor of New York and New Jersey, arriving in June of 1710. Hunter left New York and New Jersey in 1719, exchanging positions with William Burnet, the comptroller of customs. In 1727 he was appointed governor of Jamaica, where he died in 1734.

Individual documents include a list of warrants, bonds, conveyances, and papers left in the hands of Abraham De Peyster, 1719; accounts pertaining to the repair, rental, and leasing of houses and property in Amboy, New Jersey; and a 1720 valuation of Hunter's household goods at Amboy. Individuals mentioned or involved in Hunter's affairs include his attorney, James Alexander, John Barclay, and William Burnet.

subject.value: New York (State) -- Politics and government -- To 1775
